Pace, M.D., Ballantine, $14.95.
docs.abstract: Judith Lederman and Dr Candida Fink book The Ups and Downs of Raising a Bipolar Child discusses genetic and environmental factors involved in illness that may affect as many as one million children; therapies, medication and parental retraining to help bipolar families cope described; Katherine Ketcham and Dr Nicholas A Pace book Teens Under the Influence: The Truth About Kids, Alcohol and Other Drugs covers how children become addicted and variety of drugs they may become involved in taking; guides parents on ways to cope with children taking drugs and drinking alcohol; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There was a time when vegetarians and other health-conscious eaters were forced to carry coolers loaded with food from home when they traveled almost anywhere in the United States. But the world has changed, and anyone who has driven the interstate lately knows that even there, one can nearly always find something reasonably nutritious and satisfying to eat. McDonald's and other fast-food establishments include a variety of salad meals and sandwiches that are lower in fat and calories than their main selections, but still filling and rich in flavor.

headline.main: On the Road, Avoiding Pitfalls at the Pit Stops

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column describes ways to eat healthy while traveling; holds that travelers should look for healthy and low fat alternatives at well-known restaurants; Nikki and David Goldbeck's paperback guide Healthy Highways: The Traveler's Guide to Healthy Eating provides detailed state-by-state listings of vegetarian and natural food stores and restaurants; healthy food options discussed; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People with hypertension who monitor their blood pressure at home do a better job of keeping the disease under control than do people who rely solely on doctors' checkups, a new study in the British journal BMJ reports. After reviewing 18 studies involving about 2,700 patients, the researchers found that those who used home-monitoring kits tended to have combined systolic and diastolic readings about 4 points lower than the patients monitored only by doctors.
docs.abstract: Professor Francesco P Cappuccio of St George's Hospital Medical School in London leads study on benefits of home blood pressure testing; study, published in journal BMJ, shows patients who test at home have combined systolic and diastolic readings about 4 points lower than those who test only at doctor's office; possible reasons for findings discussed; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People with hypertension who monitor their blood pressure at home do a better job of keeping the disease under control than do people who rely solely on doctors' checkups, a new study in the British journal BMJ reports.    After reviewing 18 studies...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Ronald Reagan ran for president in 1980, pundits and political opponents criticized him for making contradictory statements and described him as absent-minded and inattentive. The portrayals raised questions about the health, and particularly the mental faculties, of a man who at age 69 would become the oldest to be elected president. During the campaign, Mr. Reagan agreed to let me talk to all his doctors, examine his records and then interview him about his health. On a plane from San Francisco to Denver, Mr. Reagan told me that his mother, Nellie, had been senile ''for a few years before she died'' of a stroke at age 80. Mr. Reagan said he fully expected his White House doctors to check his mental status, and he pledged to resign if he became senile while in office.

headline.main: A Recollection of Early Questions About Reagan's Health

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence K Altman discusses his personal experience talking with then President Ronald Reagan about his health and his thoughts on Reagan later being diagnosed as having Alzheimer's; holds that there is no evidence that Reagan had illness while in office; Reagan was monitored closely by team of doctors; estimated 4.5 million Americans have Alzheimer's disease, which was first identified by German psychiatrist Alois Alzheimer in 1906; Alzheimer's disease described (M)
docs.snippet: When Ronald Reagan ran for president in 1980, pundits and political opponents criticized him for making contradictory statements and described him as absent-minded and inattentive. The portrayals raised questions about the health, and particularly...

docs.lead_paragraph: Surgeons say transplant surgery for hair loss should be considered only after a doctor's evaluation and a months-long test of less drastic remedies. In 95 percent of cases, thinning hair in men and women results from a hereditary condition, androgenetic alopecia. In men, the loss usually begins at the temple and the crown. Women have a gradual thinning over the entire head.

headline.main: Weighing the Risks of New Plumage

docs.abstract: Surgeons suggest that men and women wanting to combat hair loss should be thoroughly tested by physician and consider other alternatives prior to undergoing hair transplant surgery; various conditions that cause hair loss and treatment regimens described; risks of transplants discussed (M)
docs.snippet: Surgeons say transplant surgery for hair loss should be considered only after a doctor's evaluation and a months-long test of less drastic remedies.     In 95 percent of cases, thinning hair in men and women results from a hereditary condition,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Human behavior can be reduced to a series of chemical reactions. Sleep, that puzzling but most routine of activities, is no exception. Scientists have long known that three brain chemicals -- serotonin, norepinephrine and histamine -- are involved in sleep and waking. They dwindle when people nod off and spike as people wake up. But for the first time, a recent study has found that each of the three neurotransmitters plays a distinct role. The ebb and flow of serotonin and norepinephrine affect muscle tone, keeping the body still at night, the study found, while histamine controls arousal.

headline.main: Teasing Apart Chemicals, Scientists Unlock One More of Sleep's Secrets

docs.abstract: Dr Jerome M Siegel, Greater Los Angeles Veterans Affairs Healthcare System neurobiology research chief, leads study on effects of serotonin, norepinephrine and histamine on sleep; study, published in journal Neuron, measured levels of brain chemicals in narcoleptic dogs; finds that histamine works separately from norepinephrine, not in tandem, as previously thought; suggests that insomniacs may suffer from excess of histamine; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Human behavior can be reduced to a series of chemical reactions. Sleep, that puzzling but most routine of activities, is no exception.    Scientists have long known that three brain chemicals -- serotonin, norepinephrine and histamine -- are involved...

docs.lead_paragraph: When mammals mate, it is often at times the female is most likely to become pregnant. That, after all, is the point. Is that true of humans? Maybe. A new study in the journal Human Reproduction found that women were far more likely to have intercourse on days they were most likely to conceive, even if they were trying not to have babies.
docs.abstract: Dr Allen J Wilcox of National Institute of Environmental Health Science leads study on biological component of human pregnancy; study, published in journal Human Reproduction, finds that women have more sex on days they are most likely to conceive regardless of their desire to avoid pregnancy or to get pregnant; holds there are many possible reasons for behavior; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Talk about suffering for science. To test the effectiveness of a cream intended to protect swimmers from jellyfish stings, 24 volunteers agreed to be stung with jellyfish tentacles for as long as 60 seconds. The experiment was described in the current issue of Wilderness and Environmental Medicine, a publication of the Wilderness Medical Society, and was led by scientists at Stanford University.

headline.main: Jellyfish Stings for a Good Cause

docs.abstract: Twenty-four people, primarily swimmers or surfers, volunteer to be stung by jellyfish to test effectiveness of cream touted as protection against stings; Dr Alexa Boer Kimball, Stanford University researcher and lead author of study, holds cream does reduce affects of stings; findings are published in Wilderness and Environmental Medicine; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Talk about suffering for science. To test the effectiveness of a cream intended to protect swimmers from jellyfish stings, 24 volunteers agreed to be stung with jellyfish tentacles for as long as 60 seconds.    The experiment was described in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Why are so many mastectomies performed, when less invasive lumpectomies are often an alternative? A new study reports that part of the answer may lie with the patients. A survey of more than 1,700 women conducted about six months after they had the surgery found that the bigger a patient's role in choosing treatment, the more likely she was to choose mastectomy. The findings were presented last week at a meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology.
docs.abstract: Dr Steven J Katz, University of Michigan Medical School researcher, leads study that finds women are more likely to choose mastectomy over less invasive lumpectomy when heavily involved in surgical decision to treat their breast cancer; study, based on survey of more than 1,700 women, was presented at American Society of Clinical Oncology meeting (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''How you doing, Tom?'' asked Dr. Anthony DiBiase, a Manhattan surgeon, in the midst of jabbing a lancet 1,130 times into the balding head of Tom Raybek. ''You O.K.?'' ''Yep,'' said Mr. Raybek, as mellow and relaxed on a mild tranquilizer and topical anesthetic as if he were getting a haircut, which was pretty much the opposite of what he was getting.

headline.main: Does He or Doesn't He? It's Harder to Tell

docs.abstract: New hair transplant techniques give more realistic choice for men and women dealing with thinning hair; details of procedure performed by Manhattan surgeon Dr Anthony DiBiase, who works for Bosley Inc, described; cause of routine baldness and possibility of hair cloning technology within next ten years discussed; American Society of Plastic Surgeons reports that almost 32,000 hair transplants, costing nearly third of billion dollars, were performed in US in 2003; Tom Raybek, Killington, VT, ski lodge owner's transplant described; photos; drawings (L)
